Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Torque on a Current Loop in a Magnetic Field

Torque on a Current Loop in a Magnetic Field
Topic: Electromagnetism
The torque on a Current loop (in a uniform magnetic field) is then \vec{\tau} = \vec{\mu} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}
This is reminiscent of electric Dipoles. We can, just like electric dipoles, define a type of potential energy for a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field, which is: U = - \vec{\mu} \times \vec{\textbf{B}}; \quad U\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0

Vacuum Magnetic Permeability
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Vacuum Magnetic Permeability
Topic: Electromagnetism
The vacuum magnetic permeability is a physical constant that is used in the Magnetic Field of a Moving Point Charge. It is given by \mu_{0} = 4 \pi \times 10^{-7} \text{(T m)/A}
where T is Tesla, m is meters, and A is Ampere.
It is related to the Permittivity of Free Space.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Volt
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Volt
Topic: Electromagnetism
Named in honor of Alessandro Volta, the Volt is the unit for Potential Difference. It is defined as
1 \text{ V} = 1 \text{ J/C}
where J is Joules and C is Coulomb.

Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 23-1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Voltage
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Voltage
Topic: Electromagnetism

The Electric Potential Energy per unit Charge.

If we put a tiny positive test charge q in a uniform Electric Field, it have some amount of electric potential energy U_{a} at some arbitrary point a relative to some zero. Then, the electric potential V_{a} at this point is defined as
V_{a} = \frac{U_{a}}{q} 
This gives us the potential difference between point a and the zero, b.
The unit is the Volt.


                  
                  Comparison to Mechanics 
                  
                

In Electromagnetism, many of our concepts have equivalents to Newtons Laws of Motion. Voltage has a mechanical analog of force, F. It can be thought of as voltage representing the amount of force required to hold a charge, much like a normal force holds a mass.


Electric Potential and the Electric Field
The potential difference can be derived from the Conservation of Energy as
\Delta V = V_{ba} = V_{b} - V_{a} = - \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\vec{\textbf{E}}\cdot d\vec{\ell}}
Notice that is the Vector Dot Products between the electric field and some infinitesimal displacement d \vec{\ell}. That makes this a Line Integral. 
We can go the opposite direction, as well: Electric Field Determined from Voltage.
Specific Cases
Transclude of Capacitors#^8bdbf4
Transclude of Electric-Potential-Due-To-A-Point-Charge#^79d358
Building on this point charge example, we can find the Potential Due to Any Charge Distribution.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.title: Weber Unit
Concepts/Science/Physics/Electricity-and.content:
Weber Unit
Topic: Electromagnetism
Weber Unit
The weber unit is the unit of Magnetic Flux. It is given by 1 \text{ Wb} = 1 \text{ V} \cdot \text{s}

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Ampere.title: Ampere
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Ampere.content:
Ampere
Topic: Energy
The Ampere is the unit of Electrical Charge.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.title: Conservation of Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.content:
Conservation of Energy
Topic: Energy


                  
                  Law of Conservation of Energy 
                  
                

Energy can neither be created nor destroyed, only converted from one form of energy to another.


E_{total}=K_{E} + P_{E} + Q
The total energy within a closed system is equal to the sum of the kinetic energy, potential energy, and internal/thermal energy. Alternatively, it could be stated that:
W_{net} = W_{conservative} + W_{non-conservative}
Conservation of Mechanical Energy


                  
                  Conservation of Mechanical Energy 
                  
                

If only Conservative Forces act, then the total mechanical energy of a system is conserved.


Proof
k = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} => W_{net}=\Delta K
\text{Potential Energy }  U => \Delta U = -W_{conservative}
Thus, if only conservative forces act:
\begin{aligned}
\Delta K &= -\Delta U \\
K_{f} - K_{i} &= U_{i} - U_{f}\\
U_{i} + K_{i} &= U_{f} + K_{f} \\
E_{i} &= E_{f} 
\end{aligned}


                  
                  Sample Problem 
                  
                

A roller coast includes a vertical drop of 59.4 meters. If the speed at the crest is 0 and no friction is present, what would be the speed of the roller coaster at the bottom of the drop?
E_{total} = (PE+KE)_{top} = (PE + KE)_{bottom}
Since there is no kinetic energy at the top and no potential energy at the ground, we conclude that:
PE_{top} = KE_{bottom}
Therefore:
(mgh)_{top} = (\frac{1}{2}mv^{2})_{bottom}
gh = \frac{1}{2}v^2 \to v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{(2)(-9.81 m/s^2)(-59.4)} = 34.138 m/s
The speed at the bottom is 34.1 meters per second.



References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.title: Conservative Forces
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Conserva.content:
Conservative Forces
Topic: Energy
A force is conservative if:

The work done by moving an object from an initial to final position is independent of the path taken
The work done by the force is 0 in a round trip

In other words, a conservative force can only be written as a function of position.
The three most common conservative forces in elementary physics are:

Newtons Law of Gravity
Hookes Law (Elastic Potential Energy)
Electric Potential Energy

How To Tell if a Force is Conservative
If a force is given by a Vector Field \vec{\textbf{F}}, and if curl(\vec{\textbf{F}}) = 0 and the domain where \vec{\textbf{F}} is defined is simply connected, then \vec{\textbf{F}} is conservative and is a Gradient Field and you can apply Greens Theorem.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Elastic-.title: Elastic Potential Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Elastic-.content:
Elastic Potential Energy
The work done on a spring is the area under the Force versus Elongation curve. This also equals the change in elastic potential of the system (EPE). Since a Force versus Elongation curve is linear, the area under it is a triangle, and the area of a triangle is \frac{1}{2}(base)(height), so  the elastic potential energy is:
EPE = \frac{1}{2}(F \Delta x) = \frac{1}{2}(k\Delta x^2)

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Energy.title: Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Energy.content:
Energy
Energy is the ability to cause change or the ability to do work and is measured in the SI unit Joules. All forms of energy can be measured in a unit called Joule.
1 \text{ J} = \frac{\text{ kg} \cdot \text{m}}{^2}{\text{ s}^{2}}
1 calorie = 4.186 Joules
1 Kilocalorie = 4186 Joules
Work is the process of causing matter to move against an opposing force. When matter moves, it is changing position, and that requires energy.
All forms of energy can be classified as either potential or kinetic energy.
Potential Energy
Transclude of Potential-Energy
Kinetic Energy
Transclude of Kinetic-Energy#kinetic-energy

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Heating-.title: Heating and Cooling Curves
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Heating-.content:
Heating and Cooling Curves
Temperature changes and phase transistions over time are modeled by heating curves and cooling curves. They both show the relationship between the temperature of the substance (plotted on the vertical axis), and the time that has passed (plotted on the horizontal axis).
A heating curve shows constant heating, with particles gaining energy and phase transitions from solid to liquid or liquid to gas.
A cooling curve shows constant cooling, with particles losing energy and phase transitions from gas down to solid.
The curves often have horizontal lines to show the phase transition over time.
Sample Heating Curve

Sample Cooling Curve

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Joules.title: Joules
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Joules.content:
Joules
Topic: Energy
The Joule is the SI unit for energy and Work, named after James Prescott Joule. A Joule is defined as 1 Newton Meter. That means that a Joule is the work done when a force of 1 Newton displaces a mass through a distance of 1 meter in the direction of the force. It can alternatively be described as:

1 Watt/second
\frac{\text{kg} \times \text{m}^{2}}{\text{s}^{2}}


References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Kinetic-.title: Kinetic Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Kinetic-.content:
Kinetic Energy
Topic: Energy
Kinetic energy is the energy which a particle has a result of its movement. Kinetic energy is generally defined by the formula
k = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2}
where m is the Mass of the object, v is the Velocity, and k is the kinetic energy, measured in Joules.
Angular Motion
When angular motion is involved as well as translational, you must account for the energy that is spent rotating the object. As such, the formula becomes
K = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} + \frac{1}{2}I_{cm} \omega^{2}
k is the kinetic energy, measured in Joules, m is the Mass of the object, v is the Velocity, I_{cm} is the Moment of Inertia, and \omega is the Angular Velocity.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Potentia.title: Potential Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Potentia.content:
Potential Energy
Topic: Energy
Potential energy (U) is:

stored energy
can only be defined for Conservative Forces
Defined for a system of two objects

e.g. holding up a pen increases the potential energy of the earth-pen system; this is normally omitted for brevity



The two most common examples of potential energy in Calculus-Based Physics are:

Gravitational Potential Energy: U_{grav} = mgy where m is the Mass, y is the height from some specific reference point, and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
Elastic Potential Energy: U_{s}=\frac{1}{2}kx^{2}, where k is a Spring Constant and x is the distance which the spring is compressed.

Change in Potential Energy
Conservation of Energy
Gravitational Potential Energy
Potential energy due to the elevated position of an object is called gravitational potential energy (GPE). It is the focus of Physics 04.03.
The GPE of an object depends on the mass and height of the object, as well as the gravitational acceleration.
GPE = mgh

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Power.title: Power
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Power.content:
Power
Topic: Energy
Power is defined as the energy over time, and is measured in Watts or Horsepower.
1 \text{ W} = 1 \text{ J/s}
Power in a Circuit is given by P = \frac{dq}{dt}V = IV = I^{2}R = \frac{V^{2}}{R}
where V is Voltage and I is Current. This resembles Ohms Law and the Energy Stored in a Capacitor but is different.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 25-5

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work-Ene.title: Work Energy Theorem
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work-Ene.content:
Work Energy Theorem
Topic: Energy
The work energy theorem relates Work to Kinetic Energy. Specifically, it states that the work done by the sum of all forces acting on an object is equal to the change in the kinetic energy of that object:
W = \Delta K.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work.title: Work
Concepts/Science/Physics/Energy/Work.content:
Work
Work is the application of energy. The standard equation for work is:
W = Fd
where W = the work done, measured in J, F = the applied constant force, measured in newtons, and d = the displacement the object moves in the direction of the force, measured in meters.
Work is the area under a Force versus Displacement Graph.
Work is equal to the change in kinetic energy: Work Energy Theorem
Integral
Work is much better expressed as an integral.
W = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{(F(x))dx}
Where F(x) is the force at a distance. This is important when the force varies over distance. In physics, this might be written as:
W = \int\limits_{a}^{b}{\vec{\textbf{F}} \cdot d\vec{l}}
Power
The rate at which work is done is called Power.
Other Units

Foot pound: The work accomplished when a one pound force pushes something through a distance of one foot.
Horsepower: a unit of measurement for power, 1 hp = 550 ft * lb/s = 746 Watts. 4

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Absolute Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Absolute Pressure
Topic: Fluids
What is absolute pressure? :?: Absolute pressure is the total net pressure, P = P_{0} + P_{g} \to \text{Pressure} = \text{External Pressure + Gauge Pressure}

Absolute pressure is what is typically used in equations, such as the Hydrostatic Equation, so you’ll have to convert.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Bernoulli's Equation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Bernoulli’s Equation
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
P_{1} + \frac{1}{2} \rho v_{1}^{2} + \rho g h_{1} = P_{2} + \frac{1}{2} \rho v_{2}^{2} + \rho g h
Where P is Absolute Pressure, \rho is Density, v is Velocity, and h is the height of the fluid at each point.
This equation comes from the Conservation of Energy. If you add up all the forms of energy that the liquid at any point has, it has to be constant.

The first term comes from pressure and volume being able to do Work
The second term comes from the Kinetic Energy of the liquid. This is called the kinetic energy density
The third term comes from the Potential Energy due to Newtons Law of Gravity

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Bernoulli's Principle
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Topic: Fluids
Bernoulli’s Principle
Fluid velocity and pressure are inverse. Therefore if a liquid is moving faster, it exhibits less pressure on the walls of the pipe. This, along with the Application, gives an interesting idea: narrower, faster flowing pipes put less pressure on the pipe.
See also Bernoulli’s Equation.
References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Buoyancy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Buoyancy

the buoyant force on a submerged object is equal to the Weight of the displaced fluid

When an object is placed into the water, it displaces water equal to its volume. The weight of that water is called the buoyancy.
F_{b}= \rho g V
An object is neutrally buoyant when the force of gravity = the force of buoyancy. This occurs when the Density of the object is equal to the Density of the water.
A object is negatively buoyant when gravity is stronger than buoyant force. The opposite is true for positive buoyancy.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Computational Fluid Dynamics
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
The study of Fluid Dynamics using computers.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Critical Temperature
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Critical Temperature
Topic: Fluids
At different pressures, volumes, and temperatures, a substance may or may not undergo Phase Changes. There exists a combination of pressure and temperature for each substance such that it a Gas barely transforms into a liquid, called the critical point. The temperature of this value is called the critical temperature.
In the following diagram, point c represents the critical point.



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Equation of Continuity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Equation of Continuity
Topic: Fluids
The equation of continuity for fluids relates the rate of flow at one point to another, stating that they must be equal across the fluid. This is applied in narrowing or widening pipes, for example.
\rho_{1}v_{1}A_{1} = \rho_{2}v_{2}A_{2}
\rho is density, v is velocity, and A is cross-sectional area.
Conceptual
If you have a certain amount of liquid flowing through a cross-section of a pipe in a certain period of time you can imagine that liquid is pushing on all the other water further down the pipe. Therefore the rate at which the liquid is passing through must be equal everywhere.
Application
In areas where the area is narrower, it will have to move faster.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Fluids
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Fluids
What is a fluid? :?: Something that flows, including gases, liquids, and plasmas.

What causes Pressure in a fluid? :?: The weight of the fluid and the collisions of the molecules.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Gauge Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Gauge Pressure
Topic: Fluids
What is gauge pressure? :?: Pressure relative to some reference value, e.g. 1 atm, as measured by a gauge. For example, when pumping up tires, the scale will read 0 when it is not attached to a tire even though it is under 1 atmosphere of pressure, because that is how the gauge is calibrated.


References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Hydraulics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Hydraulics
Topic: Fluids
Hydraulics rely on Pascals Principle to give mechanical advantage in some way. For example, you might lift a car using a hydraulic lift that functions by putting some force on one piston with a small area that lifts a much larger piston by a smaller amount.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Hydrostatic Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Hydrostatic Pressure
Topic: Fluids
Hydrostatic pressure is the pressure in a fluid at rest.
What does hydrostatic mean? :?: Fluid at rest.

Hydrostatic Equation
P = P_{0} + \rho gh
\text{Pressure = External Pressure + density * gravity * height or depth}
Note that this is Absolute Pressure, not Gauge Pressure.
Horizontal Line Property
Across a horizontal line, the pressure in a continuous fluid is equal.


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Ideal Gas Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Ideal Gas Law
Topic: Fluids
The Ideal Gas law is an idealized relationship between the Temperature, Pressure, quantity, and volume of a gas:
PV = nRT,
where n represents the number of moles and R = 8.314 \text{ J/(mol * K)} is the universal gas constant. 

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 17-6

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Ideal Gas
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Ideal Gas
Topic: Fluids
An ideal gas is a gas which obeys the Ideal Gas Law. Specifically, it is a gas which we make certain assumptions about so that we can more accurately and reliably model it using kinetic theory. The assumptions are:

There are a large number of molecules, N, each of mass m, moving in random directions with a variety of speeds
The molecules are, on average, separated by an amount much greater than the diameter of each molecule
Molecules obey the laws of classical mechanics, and interact only in collisions; attractive forces are negligible
Collisions are assumed to be perfectly elastic and of very short duration

Under these assumptions, we can do some pretty interesting physics to derive a relationship between the kinetic energy and the temperature of a gas.
Consider a container with a side of area A. It is filled with a gas of N molecules, each mass m. Consider a single molecule of that gas, with an initial velocity \vec{v} = v_{x}. It collides with the wall, creating a perfectly elastic collision and bouncing back with a velocity of - v_{x}. The wall therefore must exert a force of F = \frac{dP}{dt} = \frac{2mv_{x}}{dt} on the molecule. The molecule bounces back, hits the other wall, and then returns travelling a total distance of 2 \ell over a time v_{x}\Delta t \to \Delta t = \frac{2\ell}{v_{x}}. Finally, we can state that the force due to one molecule is
F = \frac{dp}{dt} = \frac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t} = \frac{2mv_{x}}{\frac{2\ell}{v_{x}}} = \frac{mv_{x}^{2}}{\ell}
Now, let us extend to all molecules.
F = \frac{m}{\ell} (v_{x1}^{2} + v_{x2}^{2} + \dots + v_{xN}^{2})
Let \bar{v} be the average velocity.
\bar{v_{x}^{2}} = \frac{v_{x1}^{2} + v_{x2}^{2} + \dots + v_{xN}^{2}}{N}
We said that the average velocity is in a random direction, so \bar{v_{x}} = \bar{v_{y}} = \bar{v_{z}}. By Pythagoras, we can say that \bar{v^{2}} = \bar{v_{x}^{2}} + \bar{v_{y}^{2}} + \bar{v_{z}^{2}}. Therefore, \bar{v^{2}} = 3\bar{v_{x}^{2}}.
F = \frac{m}{\ell}N\bar{v_{x}^{2}} = \frac{m}{\ell} N \frac{\bar{v^{2}}}{3}
The pressure on the wall is then P = \frac{F}{A} = \frac{1}{3} \frac{Nm\bar{v^{2}}}{A\ell} = \frac{1}{3} \frac{Nm\bar{v^{2}}}{V} \to PV = \frac{Nm\bar{v^{2}}}{3} = \frac{2}{3} N\left( \frac{1}{2} m\bar{v^{2}}\right)
From the Ideal Gas Law, we know that PV = NkT, so
\frac{2}{3}\left( \frac{1}{2} m\bar{v^{2}}\right) = kT
The kinetic energy is therefore \frac{3}{2} kT, and thus the average kinetic energy of molecules in an ideal gas is proportional to the absolute temperature of the gas.
To determine the average speed of molecules in a gas, use the equation
v_\text{root-mean-square} = \sqrt{\bar{v^{2}}} = \sqrt{\frac{3kT}{m}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Mean Free Path
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Mean Free Path
Topic: Fluids
The mean free path of a gas is the average distance which a molecule travels between collisions. The formula is given by
\ell_{m} = \frac{1}{4 \pi r^{2} (N/V)}
where r is the molecular radius, N is the number of molecules, and V is the volume of the container.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Navier-Stokes Equations
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Navier-Stokes Equations
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
The Navier-Stokes Equations are a series of Partial Differential Equations that describe the motion of Fluids.
They can be presented in many forms.
Incompressible, Newtonian Fluids
Let \vec{\textbf{u}} denote Velocity, \rho denote fluid Density, p denote Pressure, \mu denote Viscosity, and \vec{\textbf{F}} denote any external Force.
The Divergence Operator of the velocity is 0 (essentially, Law of Conservation of Matter):
\nabla \cdot \vec{\textbf{u}} = 0
The acceleration is dependent on internal forces and external forces:
\rho \frac{\partial \vec{\textbf{u}}}{\partial t} = - \nabla p + \mu \nabla^{2} \vec{\textbf{u}} + \rho \vec{\textbf{F}}
(note the Partial Derivatives, Gradient, and Laplace Operator).
We can develop some basic intuition for each of these terms. The gradient term implies that the the fluid will tend to accelerate from a high pressure area to a low pressure one. The viscosity term acts much like friction, but it can also spread out. The third term is the result of external forces like gravity, walls, or other restrictions on the liquid.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Pascals Principle
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Pascals Principle
Topic: Fluids
What is Pascal’s Principle? :?: The principle that the pressure throughout a fluid is equal.

Formally, Pascal’s Principle might be defined as:

A pressure change at any point in a confined and in-compressible fluid is transmitted throughout the fluid such that the same change occurs everywhere.

This is the fundamental principle through which Hydraulics work.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Pressure
Topic: Fluids
\text{Pressure} = P = \frac{F}{A}
Measured in Pascals: 1 Pa = 1 N / m^2. Also measured in kilopascals kPa, atmospheres 1 atm = 101.3 kPa, and pounds per square inch, 1 atm = 14.7 psi.
Pressure always acts perpendicular to the surface of an object.
The pressure force in a fluid is caused by:

The weight of the column of fluid above
The collisions of fluid molecules

What is pressure? :?: Force per unit area.


References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 13

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Saturated Vapor Pressure
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Saturated Vapor Pressure
Topic: Fluids
Air normally contains Vapor, and it mainly comes from Evaporation. In a closed container, when the amount of molecules in the vapor is equal to the number of molecules returning to the liquid, the gas is said to be saturated. The Pressure of the vapor when it is saturated is called the saturated vapor pressure.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Torricelli's Theorem
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Torricelli’s Theorem
Topic: Fluid Dynamics
The velocity of the fluid coming out of the spout is the same as the velocity of a single droplet of fluid that falls from the height of the surface of the fluid in the container.
This is an application of Bernoulli’s Equation - or perhaps better said to be a particular case of Bernoulli’s Principle. The total energy at the source has to be equal to the energy at the spout.
Imagine a barrel of water with a spout and hose connected at the bottom. If you pointed the hose directly upward, the outcoming water would reach just as high as the current level of water in the barrel. This is essentially the logic behind Torricelli’s Theorem.

References

Fluids in Motion: Crash Course Physics #15

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Van der Waals Equation of State
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Van der Waals Equation of State
Topic: Fluids
The Ideal Gas Law is just that — ideal. It turns out that gases don’t behave exactly like this, especially as your approach high pressures. The Van der Waals Equation of State is a way of accounting for the inaccuracies in reality.
The two Ideal Gas assumptions that the Van der Waals equation accounts for are the effects of attractive forces between molecules and the finite volume of the molecules of a gas.
If we assume that the molecules of a gas are spherical with radius r and behave like hard spheres, the smallest distance possible is between two is 2r. Thus the actual volume cannot be 0. Let b represent the unavailable volume per mole of gas. Then we have
P(V - nb) = nRT
Next, we consider the intermolecular attraction between molecules. The molecules on the edge of the gas, near the wall of a container, are slowed down by these molecular forces and therefore exert less pressure on the wall. This gives us the term \frac{a}{\left(\frac{V}{n}\right)^{2}}, combining to give us the Van der Waals Equation of State:
\boxed{\left(P + \frac{a}{\left(\frac{V}{n}\right)}^{2}\right)\left(\frac{V}{n} - b\right) = RT}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.title: Vapor
Concepts/Science/Physics/Fluid-Dynamics/.content:
Vapor
Topic: Fluids
A vapor is very similar to a gas. However, the difference is that a substance below its Critical Temperature in the gaseous state is called a vapor; above the critical temperature it is called a gas.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 18

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Bulk-.title: Bulk Modulus
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Bulk-.content:
Bulk Modulus
If an object is subjected to an inward force on all sides, its volume changes according to its material Bulk Modulus, by the equation:
\frac{\Delta V}{V_{0}}=\frac{-1}{B}\Delta P
Where \Delta V is the change in volume, V_{0} is the initial volume, B is the bulk modulus, and \Delta P is the change in Pressure.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Cente.title: Center of Mass
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Cente.content:
Center of Mass
Topic: Linear Momentum, Angular Motion

The weighted average position of the Mass in a system

You could calculate each dimension of the coordinate independently:
x_{cm}= \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n} \frac{m_{i}x_{i}}{M} 
where M is the total mass = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{m_{i}}.
You can repeat for y and z.
Planar Object
Let the center of mass of a planar object of density \delta(x,y) and mass M be (\bar{x}, \bar{y}). These coordinates are found by the following double integrals:
\bar{x} = \frac{1}{M} \iint_{R} x\delta dA; \quad \bar{y} = \frac{1}{M} \iint_{R} y\delta dA;
Volumetric
\bar{x} = \frac{1}{\text{Mass}} \iiint_{R} x \delta dV (same for y and z). This is a triple integral, techniques for which are discussed there.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 9

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Densi.title: Density
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Densi.content:
Density
Topic: Materials
Density is a measure of how much matter fits into an amount of space. It can be area, volume, or technically even linear. Typically, you will see the form:
\text{Density} = \rho = \frac{m}{V}
Where \rho is density, m is mass, and V is volume. It has units of \text{kg/}\text{m}^{3}.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Hooke.title: Hooke's Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Hooke.content:
Hooke’s Law
Topic: Materials, Conservative Forces
The relationship between the force applied to a spring and its resulting elongation is linear. The constant of proportionality k is called the Spring Constant, and the equation that relates these variables is
F = k\Delta x
where F is the force, k is the spring constant and \Delta  x is the change in length.
Notably, \Delta x \propto L, where L is the length of the spring. i.e. double the length, double the stretch.
Transclude of Elastic-Potential-Energy
Transclude of Young's-Modulus

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Mater.title: Material Stress
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Mater.content:
Material Stress
Stress can be considered the ratio of deforming force to the cross sectional area of the solid.
\text{Stress} = \frac{F}{A_{cs}}
There are three types of material stress:

Tension: Pulling
Compression: Pushing
Shear: Force parallel to the surface

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 12

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Mater.title: Materials
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Mater.content:
Materials
Stuff we make things out of!

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Sprin.title: Spring Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Sprin.content:
Spring Constant
The spring constant is a material constant that dictates how hard it is to pull a spring. It depends on:

The material’s Young’s Modulus, Y = E
The length L
Area of the cross section perpendicular to the force A_{cs}

The units of the spring constant is in dimensions of force per unit length, or N/m.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 12

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Strai.title: Strain
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Strai.content:
Strain
Strain is the ratio of the change in length of the solid to the original length of the solid. \text{Strain} = \frac{\Delta L} {L_0}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 12

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Therm.title: Thermal Stresses
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Therm.content:
Thermal Stresses
Topic: Thermodynamics
The Material Stress due to Linear Expansion is given by:
\frac{F}{A}  = \alpha E \Delta T
where \alpha is the coefficient of Linear Expansion, E is the Young’s Modulus for the material, and \Delta T is the change in Temperature.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 17

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Ultim.title: Ultimate Strength
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Ultim.content:
Ultimate Strength
The ultimate strength of a material is the maximum Material Stress that a specific material can withstand before breaking or fracturing.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 12

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Volum.title: Volume Expansion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Volum.content:
Volume Expansion
Topic: Materials
In a similar manner to Linear Expansion, a material will generally increase in volume when heated. The formula for this expansion is given by
V = V_{0}(1 + \beta) \Delta T
where \beta is the coefficient of volume expansion, typically in the range of 3\alpha, where \alpha is the coefficient of linear expansion.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Young.title: Young's Modulus
Concepts/Science/Physics/Materials/Young.content:
Young’s Modulus
The measure of the stiffness of a material is called Young’s Modulus (Y), named after Thomas Young (1773-1829). This modulus is the ratio of stress to strain for a body obeying Hooke’s Law.
The equation for Young’s Modulus is:

where Y is Young’s Modulus,
F is the deforming force
A_{cs} is the cross-sectional area
\Delta L is the change in length
L_0 is the original length of the object

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Force
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Newtons Laws of Motion
Force
A force is essentially a push or pull.
By Newton’s Second Law of Motion, the acceleration of an object is based on its mass and the force being applied.
F_{net} = ma \to a = \frac{F_{net}}{m}

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Friction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Newtons Laws of Motion
Friction
Friction is a force that counteracts motion. There are three main types of friction.
Static Friction
The friction that must be overcome to start moving. Also referred to as the force of friction between two objects at rest relative to each other.
F_{s} \leq \mu_{s}\times F_{n}
Kinetic Friction
The force which counteracts an object from moving.
F_{k}=\mu_{k}\times F_{n}
Rolling Friction
The friction that occurs from an object not being perfectly round.
Car Tires
Car tires are generally thought of as being static friction, because a perfect circle rolling has only one point of contact, which is instantaneously at rest relative to the road.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Inertial Frames of Reference
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Inertial Frames of Reference
An inertial frame of reference is one where the velocity is constant. This means you can be moving, as long as you are not accelerating (that includes changing direction!)


                  
                  The Principle of Galilean Relativity 
                  
                

Newton’s Laws of Motion apply equally in any inertial frame of reference.



There is No Special Frame of Reference
All frames of reference are considered equal. It is perfectly valid for a cyclist traveling at a constant 20 mph to say that a passerby, who from their frame of reference isn’t moving, has a velocity of -20 mph.

References
Modern Physics; Chapter 1

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Internal and External Forces
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Internal and External Forces
When one object in a Physics System puts force on another object in a system, it is considered an internal force.
An external force is caused by an object outside the system.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Keplers Laws
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Keplers Laws
Kepler was a famous 16-17th century mathematician and astronomer, most notable for his discovery of 3 laws which govern the motion of planets.
1st Law


                  
                  Kepler's 1st 
                  
                

The planets move in elliptical orbits, with the sun as a focus.


2nd Law


                  
                  Kepler's 2nd 
                  
                

Planets cover equal area in equal times.



3rd Law


                  
                  Kepler's 3rd 
                  
                

A planet’s orbital period is proportional to the cube of its orbit.
T^{2} \propto r^{3}

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Kinematics
Kinematic Equations
Constant Acceleration
The following four equations govern basic kinematics with constant acceleration. They can be derived from
x = x_{0}+v_{0}t+ \frac{1}{2}at^{2}
v=v_{0}+at
v_{\text{avg}}=\frac{v+v_{0}}{2}
v^{2}=v_{0}^{2}+ 2a(x -x_{0})

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Collisions in Two Dimensions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Collisions in Two Dimensions
Collisions in two dimensions are a little tricky because you need to know all four vector components to find the resulting vectors.
Special Case: Elastic Collision of Equal Mass
Suppose a 2-D elastic collision between equal mass objects, and that object B is at rest. The result of the collision is that the two objects (A + B) will move apart at right angles.
This is useful for billiard ball collisions.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Collisions
Collisions are interactions between two or more objects in a Physics System. Total momentum is conserved in all collisions. There are two types of collisions, classified as:
Elastic Collisions
Inelastic Collisions
Many real-life collisions are classified as being kinetic for simplicity sake, but they rarely are truly conservative.
Collisions in Two Dimensions

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Elastic Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Elastic Collisions
In an elastic collision, the total Kinetic Energy remains constant.
One Dimensional Elastic Collisions
The following equations allow you to determine the final speeds of two objects, a and b in an elastic collision, assuming that b is at rest at the start of the problem. You can manipulate your frame of reference in order to make this true.
V_{a}' = \left(\frac{m_{a}-m_{b}}{m_{a}+m_{b}}\right) V_{a}
V_{b}' = \left(\frac{2m_{a}}{m_{a}+m_{b}}\right)V_{a}
The speed of approach of the two objects is exactly equal to the speed of the separation of the two objects after the collision:
V_{b}' - V_{a}' = V_{a}
***

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Impulse
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Impulse
An impulse is the change in Linear Momentum.
\Delta \vec{P} = \vec{F}_{net avg} \Delta t
An impulse has units of \vec{J} or Newton seconds.
The impulse is the same for a large force acting over a short time or a small force acting over a large time.
In integral form:
\vec{J} = \int\limits_{t1 }^{t2}{(\vec{\textbf{F}}_{\text{ net external}})dt}

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Inelastic Collisions
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Linear Momentum
Inelastic Collisions
A collision in which the total Kinetic Energy does not remain constant. Note the special case of Perfectly Inelastic Collision, where the objects stick together.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum
Topic: Linear Momentum


                  
                  Conservation of Linear Momentum 
                  
                

If the net external force acting on a system is zero, then the total linear momentum of the system is constant or conserved.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Linear Momentum
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Linear Momentum
\vec{P} = m\vec{v}
Note that momentum has a direction, unlike Kinetic Energy.
The rate of change of momentum is equal to the net force:
\sum\limits \vec{F} =  \frac{d\vec{P}}{dt}
This feels quite natural as if there is no net force there will be no change in momentum. The idea doesn’t really tell us anything new about single objects, but is instead useful for systems of objects.
Momentum is often conserved. Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum.
The units for momentum are just \frac{\text{ kg}\text{ m}}{\text{s}}. There isn’t a common name for this.

Perfectly Inelastic Collision
A collision in which the objects stick together. There is only one final velocity.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Newton's Law of Gravity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Newton’s Law of Gravity
Every mass in the universe attracts every other mass in the universe with a force that is directly proportional to the product of the two masses involved and is inversely proportional to the square of the distance separating them.
F_{g} = G\frac{m_{1} \times m_{2}}{r^{2}}
G equals the gravitational constant \dfrac{6.67 E^{-11} N * m}{kg^2}, the masses are measured in kilograms, and the distance is measured in meters.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Topic: Kinematics
Projectile Motion
Projectile motion is an application of the Kinematic Equations for constant acceleration when the only force of acceleration is gravity. In other words, the projectile object is in Free Fall.
Equations

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:

Rolling Motion
Rolling motion occurs when there is translational and angular motion.
For it to occur without slipping,
v_{cm} = R \omega

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Velocity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Velocity
Velocity is a vector that denotes how fast and in what direction something is moving.
Mathematically, it is written as \vec{v} = \frac{d \vec{s}}{dt}
where \vec{s} represents the displacement.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.title: Weight
Concepts/Science/Physics/Newtonian-Mecha.content:
Weight
The weight of an object is defined in two ways:

The mass of the object times the force of gravity: W = mg
The value measured on a scale

The issue with the second definition is that a scale will read different values if you are accelerating. I suppose that mg might be different too…
Unit
If W = mg, then the SI Units for weight are \text{ kg} \times \text{m/s}^{2}, which is called a Newton (N).

Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Index-of.title: Index of Refraction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Index-of.content:
Index of Refraction
A medium is a material through which light or some other wave passes.
Different transparent mediums have different optical densities, based on the speed of light in the material. For example, light travels faster in air than in glass.
Each transparent material is then assigned a value called an index of refraction. The greater the index, the slower that light travels. The symbol for the index of refraction is n, and the equation is:
n =\frac{c}{v}
Where n represents the index of refaction without a unit,
c represents the speed of light in a vacuum. This is a constant 3.00 E8 \frac{m}{s}.
v represents the speed of light in the specific material. The unit must agree with the unit for c.
Index of Refraction for Common Substances

































SubstanceIndex of Refractionair1.00ethyl alcohol1.36water1.33glass1.52ice1.31diamond2.42

Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Snells-L.title: Snell's Law
Concepts/Science/Physics/Optics/Snells-L.content:
Snell’s Law
Snell’s Law allows use to predict the path of light as it travels from one medium to another. Many scientists tried to find a mathematical relationship for this, but the discovery came at the hand of Willebrord Snell, a Duth mathematician.
The Snell’s Law Equation
n_{1} \sin{\theta_{1}} = n_{2} \sin{\theta_{2}}
Where n_{1} is the index of refraction of the first medium, n_{2} is the second, \theta_{1} is the angle of incidence, in degrees, and \theta_{2} is the angle of refraction.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Physics-System.title: Physics System
Concepts/Science/Physics/Physics-System.content:
Physics System
Topic: Linear Momentum
A physics system is just a collection of objects.
Closed System
A closed system allows energy to flow in and out, but not matter.
Open System
In an open system, energy and matter can both flow in and out.
Isolated System
An isolated system, generally used as an ideal, is a system in which neither mass nor energy can flow into or out of.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Electrons
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Electrons
Electrons are negatively charged subatomic particles that orbit the nuclei of Atoms. A single electron has one negative Elementary Charge, denoted -e.
Electrons form the basis of electricity, magnetism, and more. Additionally, they are fundamental to the field of Quantum Mechanics.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Photons
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Photons
Photons are a fundamental particle, like Electrons. They are bundles, or quanta, of light.
In certain experiments, it is observed that light behaves exactly like a wave. Such as Young’s Experiment with the double slits. Light also reflects, just like Waves.
However, certain other experiments with light show that light travels as photons in quanta, containing certain measurable amounts of energy. As a result, the nature of light is now called the wave-particle duality. It is accepted that light will behave as a wave under some conditions, and a particle under others. This a conundrum that is difficult to understand.
The energy of a photon is equal to the frequency times Planck’s constant: E = hf

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Planck's Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Planck’s Constant
Planck’s constant, denoted by h, is a fundamental physical constant. A photon has energy equal to its Frequency multiplied by h.
In SI Units, it has the exact value h = 6.62607015 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J}\cdot \text{Hz}^{-1}.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Quantum Mechanics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Quantum Mechanics


                  
                  Quantum Mechanics 
                  
                

The study of the behavior of nature at a scale below the atom.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Strong Interaction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Strong Interaction
The Strong Interaction is a Fundamental Forces that confines Quarks into Protons, Neutrons, and other Hadrons. It also binds hadrons together, where it is called the nuclear force.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.title: Strong Nuclear Force
Concepts/Science/Physics/Quantum-Mechani.content:
Strong Nuclear Force
The strong nuclear force acts between Hadrons, most commonly observed between the Protons and Neutrons in the Nucleus of Atoms. The nuclear force is strong enough to overcome the force caused by the Electrical Fields of like charges when protons are placed near each other, allowing for nuclei to bind together.
Note that this is NOT the Strong Interaction

Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Eins.title: Einstein Notation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Eins.content:
Topic: Tensors
Einstein Notation
In tensor math, you generalize by summing over a list of indices a lot, for example
\sum\limits_{i=1}^{3} a_{i}x_{i} = a_{1}x_{1} + a_{2}x_{2} + a_{3}x_{3}
Einstein notation is a shorthand for this:
\sum\limits_{i=1}^{3} a_{i}x_{i} \to a_{i}x_{i}
In this case, i is called a Dummy Index.
Rules

Any twice-repeated index in a single term is summed over.

a_{ij}b_{j} = a_{i1}b_{1} + a_{i2}b_{2} + a_{i2}b_{2}
You can replace a “dummy index” with anything that is not already in the expression and that is over the same range.


A Free Index is not summed over.
No index may occur 3 or more times in a given term.
In an equation involving Einstein notation, the free indices on both sides must match

x_{i} = a_{ij}b_{j} \quad \checkmark
A_{i} = B_{ij} \quad \times



Non-identities

a_{ij}(x_{i} + y_{i}) \neq a_{ij}x_{i} + a_{ij}y_{j}
If you expand it out, the left hand side has highest terms of i = 2 and j = 2, so both i and j are dummy indices. However in the right handside the left term has a free variable j and a dummy variable i, and the right has the inverse. These are inconsistent.
a_{ij}x_{i}y_{j} \neq a_{ij}x_{j}y_{i}
We have dummy indices on both sides, however the coefficients are different when you expand so these aren’t equal.

Identities

a_{ij}(x_{j} + y_{j}) = a_{ij}x_{j} + a_{ij}y_{j}
a_{ij}x_{i}y_{j} = a_{ij}y_{j}x_{i} - commutative multiplication
(a_{ij} + a_{ji})x_{i}x_{j} = 2a_{ij}x_{i}x_{j}


References
Einstein Summation Convention: an Introduction
Einstein Notation: Proofs, Examples, and Kronecker Delta

Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Spec.title: Special Relativity
Concepts/Science/Physics/Relativity/Spec.content:
Topic: Laws of Physics
Special Relativity
Special relativity is the idea proposed by Einstein to solve the conundrum that the speed of light is constant regardless of your speed. It is the special case of General Relativity where both frames of reference are inertial.
The Conundrum
As described in Inertial Frames of Reference, there is no special frame of reference, and all laws of motion apply equally. However, we have observed that the speed of light is constant regardless of how you are moving. That is contradictory; if you are moving at the speed of light towards a flashlight, shouldn’t the light particles be traveling towards you at a speed of 2c?
Well, to solve that discrepancy, Einstein devised the idea of relativity; that time and space distort around an object, becoming more distorted as the object moves at a larger percentage of c.
A famous example of this is clocks. If you have three stationary clocks at different places, they will all see time in the same manner; after an hour has passed, all should show that an hour has passed. Now, take one of the clocks and let it move at 95% the speed of light. In the time in which the two stationary clocks observe 1 hour, the moving clock will only experience:
\Delta t' = \beta \Delta t = 1 hr\times \sqrt{1 - \frac{(0.95c)^{2}}{c^{2}}} \times \frac{60 \text{ minutes}}{1hr} = 18.7 \text{ minutes}
If you stopped the moving clock after that 1 hour, you would find that it read a dramatically different value from that of the two that were stationary the entire time.

References

Concepts/Science/Physics/Scalars.title: Scalars
Concepts/Science/Physics/Scalars.content:
Scalars
Scalars are quantities that can be described completely by their magnitude or size are called scalar quantities. Common examples are:

Distance
Speed
Mass
Time
You can add scalar quantities together if their units are the same.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Significant-Fig.title: Significant Figures
Concepts/Science/Physics/Significant-Fig.content:
Significant Figures
Topic: Measurement
Significant figures are the amount of numbers that are significant to our final figure. The number of significant figures is determined by the measurement tool.
There is some uncertainty in every measurement. Every measurement has a number of known digits + 1 uncertain digit.
The number of significant figures is determined by the measurement, not the unit, so when you convert you can never gain accuracy. This is why significant figures have rules for 0s.
The result of a calculation has as many significant figures as the number used in the calculation with the fewest sig figs. The exception is addition/subtraction, when you use decimal places.
If an answer matches an official answer except for the final digit of the figure, it is normally acceptable. Think about answers with the context of units and significant figures before turning an assignment in.
Rules for Significant Figures

All non-zero numbers are significant
Zeros between non-zero digits
Trailing zeroes only when there is a decimal point
Leading zeros are not significant


Flashcards
How many significant figures are in 0.01? (…):?:1

How many significant figures are in 22.95? (…):?:4

How many significant figures are in 0.301? (…):?:3

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Adiabatic Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Adiabatic Processes
In an adiabatic process, no Heat flow occurs; typically due to very short time periods, or extremely well insulated systems.
Adiabatic Problem Solving
Q = 0, so by the First Law of Thermodynamics,
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = -W
It can also be derived that, if you let \gamma = \frac{C_{p}}{C_{v}} (see Molar Specific Heat),
PV^{\gamma} = \text{constant}
For an ideal diatomic gas at or near room temperature, \gamma is 1.4.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Boltzmann Constant
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Boltzmann Constant
The Boltzmann Constant, denoted k_{b}, is an extremely prevalent value in thermodynamics. It is used in the Ideal Gas Law, quantifying Entropy, and Thermal Radiation. It is given the value
k_{b} = \frac{R}{N_{A}} = 1.38 \times 10^{-23}  \text{ J/K}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19; 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Calorimetry
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Calorimetry
Calorimetry is the techniques used to solve for the temperature or energy required to change the temperature of a substance. It involves Heat and Latent Heat. A calorimeter attempts to isolate the system, so that no mass or energy flows into or out. Most problems rely on the assumption that the system is isolated, such that
\sum\limits Q =0


                  
                  What is the final temperature of the system?
                  
                

200 cubic centimeters of tea at 95 degrees Celsius are poured into a 150 gram cup at 25 degrees Celsius. What will be the common final temperature T of the tea and cup when equilibrium is reached? Assume the system is isolated.
We assume that tea is approximately water. 1 cc of water is 1 gram, so we have 200 grams of water at 95 degrees Celsius. The specific heat of water is c_{w}. The specific heat of glass is c_{g} and there are 150 grams.
\begin{aligned} \sum\limits Q &= 0\\ 0 &= m_{w}c_{w}(T-T_{tea}) + m_{c}c_{c}(T-T_{cup})\\ 0 &= m_{w}c_{w}T - m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T - m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}\\ m_{w}c_{w}T + m_{c}c_{c}T &= m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}\\ T &= \frac{m_{w}c_{w}T_{tea} + m_{c}c_{c}T_{cup}}{m_{w}c_{w} + m_{c}c_{c}}\end{aligned}
Then you simply substitute.



References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Carnot Engine
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Carnot Engine
The Carnot Engine, pioneered by a French general in Napelon’s army, is an idealized reversible engine that would be optimally efficient.
The cycle of the engine goes like this:
flowchart TD

A[Isovolumetric Expansion] --> B[Adiabatic Expansion] --> C[Isothermal Compression] --> D[Adiabatic Compression] --> A

Restrictions
A Carnot Engine must, by definition, be reversible. That means each leg must be reversible. However, Friction is non-reversible, so a Carnot Engine assumes no friction. Obviously this is an idealized model.
Efficiency
In a Carnot Engine, the efficiency is
\frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}} = \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}} \to e_\text{max} = 1 - \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}
This can actually be generalized to say that ALL Heat Engines are bounded in efficiency by the temperature high and low of their cycle.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Coefficient of Performance
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Coefficient of Performance
The coefficient of performance is closely related to the Heat Efficiency of a heat engine. The coefficient of performance instead describes the “efficiency” of a fridge, AC, heat pump, or minisplit. These are essentially heat engines in reverse; you use work (electricity) to extract heat from a colder environment.
For a fridge/AC, the coefficient of performance is
CoP = \frac{Q_{L}}{W}  = \frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}
and the ideal situation gives
CoP_\text{max} = \frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}
For a heat pump, it is instead
CoP = \frac{Q_{H}}{W} = \frac{Q_{H}}{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}; \quad CoP_\text{max} = \frac{T_{H}}{T_{H}-T_{L}}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20’

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Entropy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Entropy
Entropy is a measure of disorder. It is a state variable. It is given the symbol S and measured in Joules per Kelvin.
Changes in Entropy
We approximate that, at the same Temperature, a change in entropy is given by
\Delta S = \frac{Q}{T}
This gives us the very important fact that when heat flows from hot to cold, as described by the Second Law of Thermodynamics, entropy increases. One way to conceptualize this is that a small change in an already very disorderly situation has less of an effect than a small change in a very orderly system. This change in entropy formula is more accurately stated as
dS = \frac{dQ}{T}
Quantifying Entropy
It is far easier to calculate a change in entropy than to give an exact value. However, it is a state variable, so a given state must have some exact amount of entropy. To calculate this, we first consider the idea of macro and microstates. A macrostate is a combination of state variables, including pressure, temperature, volume, and entropy. A microstate is one possible way in which a system of particles and arrange themselves to get a specific macrostate. It turns out that this number is enormous. If you denote the number of microstates as \Omega, then Boltzmann found that entropy is
S = k_{b} \ln{\Omega}
where k_{b} is the Boltzmann Constant.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Equipartition of Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Equipartition of Energy
The theory of the equipartition of energy states that each Degree of Freedom of an Ideal Gas equally contains approximately \frac{1}{2}kT energy. A monoatomic gas therefore has an Internal Energy of \frac{3}{2}kT, because it only has translational modes. Now you would assume that diatomic gas might have 6 degrees of freedom, 3 translational and 3 rotational, but one of the rotational axes has such a small moment of inertia that it is ignored. There is also the vibrational modes, but these are only active above roughly 1000 Kelvin. Therefore, a diatomic gas generally has
E_\text{int} = \frac{5}{2}kT = \frac{5}{2} nRT
of internal energy. This is the value generally used for air.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
First Law of Thermodynamics
The first law of thermodynamics states that, for a closed system,
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = Q - W
where E_\text{int} is the Internal Energy of a system, Q is the Heat flow into the system, and W is the Work done by the system. Note the sign convention.  

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Gas Laws
Heat Efficiency
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat Efficiency
In a Heat Engine, there is a concept called efficiency. It reflects how much Work you get out for a certain amount of Heat input:
\text{Efficiency} = e = \frac{\text{what you get out}}{\text{what you put in}} = \frac{W}{Q_{H}}
In a heat engine, W = Q_{H} - Q_{L}, so
e = \frac{Q_{H}-Q_{L}}{Q_{H}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{L}}{Q_{H}}
There is a related concept called the Coefficient of Performance for cooling objects like fridges and air conditioners.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Heat Engines
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat Engines
Heat engines are objects which take in heat and produce work.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Heat Flow
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat Flow
Heat can flow in three main ways:
Transclude of Thermal-Conduction#thermal-conduction
Transclude of Thermal-Radiation#thermal-radiation
Transclude of Thermal-Convection#thermal-convection

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Heat
Heat is the amount of thermal energy flowing from one substance to another. It is the energy that transfers from one object to another because of a temperature difference. Matter contains several forms of energy, but it does not contain heat. Instead, heat is energy in transit moving from a body of higher temperature to a body of lower temperature. Once the heat is transferred, the energy is no longer considered to be heat.
Transclude of Thermal-Equilibrium
Heat Transfer
To calculate the quantity of heat transfer related to a temperature change of a substance, use this equation:
Q = mc\Delta T
Where Q = the quantity of heat, measured in Joules (J)
m is the Mass of the substance, measured in Kilograms (kg)
c is the Specific Heat capacity of the substance, measured in \frac{J}{kg*C \degree}
\Delta T is the change in temperature of the substance, measured in C \degree
Transclude of Latent-Heat

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Internal Energy
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Internal Energy
A Physics System has an inherent amount of Energy, which arises from the molecular motion of matter. The amount is represented by U or E_\text{int}, and is measured in Joules. The change in internal energy of a closed system is represented in the First Law of Thermodynamics.
For an Ideal Gas, the change is calculated as
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = n C_{v} \Delta T

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isobaric Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isobaric Processes
Iso = same, baric = pressure. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the Pressure is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
An isobaric PV diagram

Isobaric Problem Solving
In an isobaric process, the Work is
W = P\Delta V

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isothermal Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isothermal Processes
Iso = same, thermal = Temperature. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the temperature is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
The following image shows a pressure-volume diagram for an isothermal process.

Isothermal Problem Solving
In an ideal gas, the internal energy only depends on the temperature. Since the temperature remains constant, we know that, by the First Law of Thermodynamics,
E_\text{int} = Q - W = 0 \to \boxed{Q = W}
It can also be found, using the integral in Work In Volume Changes that the work done in isothermically going from volume A to volume B is
W = nRT \ln{\left(\frac{V_{b}}{V_{a}}\right)}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Isovolumetric Processes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Isovolumetric Processes
Iso = same, volumetric = volume. This is a Thermodynamic Processes in which the volume is kept constant. We assume the Mass also stays constant.
PV diagram

Isovolumetric Problem Solving
If the volume remains constant, than the work done on the system is 0, so
\Delta E_{\text{int}} = Q

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Latent Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Latent Heat
The latent heat of fusion is defined as the amount of Heat one unit Mass of material, at its melting point, must absorb to change from the solid phase to the liquid phase with no change in temperature. See Phase Changes. The latent heat of vaporization is the same for boiling.
If you are trying to calculate the heat transfer related to a phase change, use the equation below:
Q=m \cdot H_f||H_v
where Q is the quantity of heat in J, m is the mass in kg, and H_f is the latent heat of fusion or H_v is the latent heat of vaporization

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Laws of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Laws of Thermodynamics
The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
There is no net flow of heat between two systems in thermal contact that have the same temperature.
The First Law of Thermodynamics
In a closed system, the total amount of heat energy added to a system is equal to the increase in the internal energy of the system plus the work done by the system.
Q = W + \Delta U
where Q = the heat added,
W = the work done,
U = the internal energy of an object.
See First Law of Thermodynamics.
Sample Problem


                  
                  Sample First Law of Thermodynamics Problem 
                  
                

While playing tennis, Joan does 5.5 E7 J of work and gives off 2.3 E7 J of heat. What is the change in Joan’s internal energy?
Q = -2.3 E7 J; negative because it is given off to the environment
W = 5.5 E7 J; positive because the work is done on the environment
\Delta U = ? = Q - W = (-2.3 E7 J) - (5.5 E7 J) = -7.8 E7 J


The Second Law of Thermodynamics
Heat itself never flows from a cold object to a hot object. Second Law of Thermodynamics.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Linear Expansion
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Linear Expansion
Materials change in size when they heat up or cool off; they expand or contract. Generally, a material expands when Temperature rises. The amount of expansion per Celsius (or Kelvin) degree is an intrinsic property of a substance. This property is called the coefficient of linear expansion (\alpha).
The equation for calculating how much a substance will increase linearly with a change in temperature is shown below:
\Delta L = \alpha L_{0} \cdot \Delta T
where \Delta L is the change in length, \alpha is the coefficient of linear expansion, L_0 is the original length, and \Delta T is the change in temperature.
An alternative form is given by
\ell = \ell_{0}(1 + \alpha \Delta T)

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Molar Specific Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Molar Specific Heat
The Specific Heat of a Ideal Gas depends on the type of process in which the Temperature is being changed. This is because during an Isovolumetric Processes no work is being done to expand the container, so all heat flow goes into raising the temperature, while in an Isobaric Processes some energy must be spent to do work to expand, so not all energy increases temperature.
Constant Volume: Q = nC_{v} \Delta T
Constant Pressure: Q = nC_{p} \Delta T
Interestingly, a result can be found that shows that the relationship between C_{v} and C_{p} is almost exactly the Universal Gas Constant.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Second Law of Thermodynamics
The second law of thermodynamics can be stated in many ways. First, note that Entropy (S) is disorder.

In any natural process, \Delta S \geq 0
Heat naturally or spontaneously flows from hot to cold
There is no such thing as a perfect Heat Engines; you can’t have 100% Heat Efficiency.

While these distinct definitions may seem disconnected, they can be all explained to mean the same thing using PV diagrams and a bit of trickery.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 20

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Specific Heat
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Specific Heat
The specific heat of a material specifies how much Energy is required to raise a kilogram of the material by one degree Celsius. Each material has a different value, and these values change ever-so-slightly with temperature.
Transclude of Molar-Specific-Heat#molar-specific-heat

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Temperature
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Temperature
The temperature of a sample of Matter is a measure of the average Kinetic Energy of the Molecules that make up that sample.
In everyday speech, Heat and temperature are related, but they are scientifically subtly different. Heat is an amount of Thermal Energy, whereas temperature is a property of a sample.
Nearly all matter expands when its temperature increases, and contracts when its temperature decreases. A common thermometer measures temperature by using a liquid that expands or contracts, like mercury. This phenomenon is called Linear Expansion.
Temperature is an Intensive Property. It is measured by the SI unit known as the Kelvin.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Conduction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Conduction
Two materials in contact with one another have a tendency to transfer Heat. On a molecular level, this occurs because the hotter object (or part of an object) has more molecular motion than the cold. When the molecules in the hot air vibrate more quickly, they will collide more often with the cooler ones, transferring energy, which propagates through the medium. Metals are good at this process because of free Electrons, which is also why they are good Electrical Conductors.
It is experimentally found that the heat flow Q over a time interval t is given by
\frac{Q}{t} = kA \frac{T_{1}-T_{2}}{\ell}
where k is a constant of thermal conductivity (in units J/(s * m * K)), A is the cross-sectional area of the material, \ell is the thickness of the material, and T_{1}, T_{2} are the temperatures.
You often see this represented in differential terms, with a temperature gradient:
\frac{dQ}{dt} = -kA \frac{dT}{dx}
Thermal Constant
Materials with high thermal conductivity are said to be good conductors. Those with low values are said to be good insulators.
R-Values
Typically measured in Imperial units, a materials R-value measures how good of a insulator it is.
R = \frac{\ell}{k}

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Convection
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Convection
Convection is the process whereby heat flows due to the bulk movement of molecules from one location to another inside a Fluids.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Equilibrium
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Thermal Equilibrium
When heat spontaneously flows from a warmer substance to a cooler one and the objects reach the same temperature, we say that the objects have reached thermal equilibrium.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Thermal Radiation
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Thermal Radiation
Objects are said to radiate heat, which is the result of the emission of Electromagnetic Waves. The rate at which an object radiates heat has been found to be proportional to the fourth power of the Kelvin temperature, T. The rate of Heat Flow is given by the equation
\frac{Q}{t} = \epsilon \sigma AT^{4}
where \epsilon = [0, 1] is the emissivity of the material, \sigma is the Sigmund-Boltzmann Constant, \sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{W/m}^{2} \cdot \text{K}^{4}, and A is the surface area of the emitting object.
Objects with a high emissivity are found to also have a high rate of absorption; that is, a good emitter is a good absorber.  

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Ultraviolet Catastrophe
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Ultraviolet Catastrophe
In the study of radiation, classical theory predicted that the energy of radiation caused by vibration could be of any energy. This idea, however, predicted that an ideal emitter would have emit an unbounded amount of energy, which obviously could not be true.
The ultraviolet catastrophe caused much upheaval in classical physics, but was ultimately resolved by Planck’s discovery that energy is discrete. Planck stated that radiation could only have values of hf, where f is the frequency and h is the eponymous Planck’s constant, h = 6.64 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J/s}.
While Planck discovered this idea, he did not have strong justification for it. It was Albert Einstein who explained the discreteness by proposing what was later named the photon, at least according to my physics professor.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.title: Work In Volume Changes
Concepts/Science/Physics/Thermodynamics/.content:
Topic: Thermodynamics
Work In Volume Changes
When the volume of an Ideal Gas changes, it must do some amount of Work to expand. This amount is given by
W = \int\limits_{V_{a}}^{V_{b}}{PdV}
where W is the Work in Joules, V_{a} and V_{b} are the starting and ending volumes, and P is the Pressure of the gas. This idea is very important for the First Law of Thermodynamics and the Thermodynamic Processes.

References
Physics for Scientists & Engineers with Modern Physics; Chapter 19

Concepts/Science/Physics/Ticker-Tape-Dia.title: Ticker Tape Diagrams
Concepts/Science/Physics/Ticker-Tape-Dia.content:
Ticker Tape Diagrams
A common way to analyze motion is with ticker tape diagrams. They mark equal time intervals and measures the distance between dots to ascertain the motion of the object.
The following list is ticker-tape patterns matched with what it means about the motion of an object:

Equally-spaced dots = Constant speed
More spaces between the equally-spaced dots = Faster motion
Spacing between consecutive dots increasing   =  Accelerating
Spacing between consecutive dots decreasing  = Decelerating
A bunch of dots bundled in one location = Rest































Type of Line on the GraphPosition-Time GraphSpeed-Time GraphA zero horizontal lineThe object is standing still at the point of referenceThe object is at rest.A non-zero horizontal lineThe object is standing still at some location away from the point of referenceThe object is moving at a constant speedAn increasing diagonal lineThe object is moving away from the point of referenceThe object is speeding up.A decreasing diagonal lineThe object is moving closer to the point of reference.The object is slowing down.

Concepts/Science/Physics/Unit-Fraction.title: Unit Fraction
Concepts/Science/Physics/Unit-Fraction.content:
Unit Fraction
Topic: Measurement
In the context of units and measurements, a unit fraction is a fraction that expresses the relationship between two units. For example, there are 2.54 centimeters in 1 inch, which can be expressed as \frac{2.54 \text{ cm}}{1 \text{ in}}.
